abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was modest,
            and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory,. The lessons learned indicate that empowering
            communities was very successful and critical for the success
            of this project. The channeling of funds from the Project
            Implementation Unit (PIU) through the Rural District
            Councils (RDCs) to the community project account was unique
            in Zimbabwe and became popular in promoting a bottom up
            approach to development. Champions in government were
            critical for manifesting government ownership and the
            country still has good technical people who are committed to
            improving the quality of peoples lives. The Government for
            example, continued to fund Community Action Project (CAP)
            from the national budget disbursing funds to communities
            directly, following the CAP Operational Manual, although the
            funds were a one time payment and not given in tranches.
            Clear guidance on how to deal with ICR processing in a
            situation where the project was cancelled. Guidance would
            assist in preparing an ICR before the institutional memory
            is lost.

4654479.trustfund:
TF023707-AFRICA POVERTY MONITORING &
            ANALYSIS PRG,TF029565-PHRD-COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF036171-ZIMBABWE - COMMUNITY ACTION PROJECT,TF039426-ZAMBIA - SOCIAL INVESTMENT FUND
            & ZW CAPACITY BLDG PROJECTS

abstracts.cdata!:
The key objective of the Community
            Action Project is to focus on poverty reduction through: (a)
            completing the macroeconomic agenda or reform and private
            sector development in order to foster sustained growth; (b)
            strengthening rural development and natural resources
            management including the empowerment of local communities to
            manage economic and social development: and (c) promoting
            poverty reduction through human resources investments,
            effective social safety nets, improved targeting and regular
            monitoring of welfare indicators. The components include:
            (i) community sub-projects (including social mobilization,
            infrastructure, improved natural resources management,
            training and capacity building for local communities); (ii)
            poverty monitoring and analysis (technical assistance, study
            fund, survey enhancement, training and capacity-building,
            workshops, dissemination); and (iii) Community Action
            Project (CAP) institutional support (administration and
            operating costs, beneficiary assessments, Environmental
            Impact Assessment, training and capacity building for CAP staff).
